Basic Music Production

Pickup Connections
Or, how to Record Guitar Music to your Computer

The Basics

What do I need?

  • Must-Haves
  • Optional Equipment
  • an electric guitar or bass guitar
  • an audio interface
  • a computer
  • ¼ inch TS cable(s)
  • an amplifier
  • a microphone
  • XLR cable(s)
  • DI Box (Direct Box)
  • a DAW (digital audio workstation)

FAQ

What is a pickup?

A pickup on your guitar captures the vibrations of your guitar strings and converts them to an electrical signal. This is an example of a transducer, which converts one form of energy into another. Specifically, since the guitar sound is an input to your system, it is an input transducer.

What is an audio interface?

Computers don’t understand electrical signals. An audio interface translates them into binary signals that the computer understands.

Before recording guitar, you should be familiar with your audio interface, its gain settings and how to set levels.

Connecting a Guitar ...or a mic!

Turn down gain

Turn the input gain/trim knob(s) all the way down on the audio interface and amplifier.

Turn down speakers

You’ve only got two ears, so avoid unpleasant surprise sounds!

Connect the gear

Plug in your guitar and/or microphone.

Adjust the levels

Play a sample and adjust the levels.

Guitars with passive pickups tend to have a low level, so the input gain may need to be higher than for a microphone. If the guitar has active pickups, however, then its level may be high.

Prepare to disconnect your gear

Also turn off the gain and speakers before disconnecting gear.

Hooking it All Up Or, Recording Methods

About Me

I’m Mariya Lysenkova. I’m a programmer and writer based in Stockholm, Sweden. I’m new to music production, and I'm very excited about learning!

I’ve put together these lessons - and this site - as part of the Introduction to Music Production MOOC from the Berklee College of Music. Please send feedback to my first name dot last name at gmail.com. Thanks for reading!
